questions.text: Which of the following is a complete sulcus?
questions.solution:
The collateral sulcus is a complete sulcus. A complete sulcus is one that is deep enough to indent the wall of a ventricle.

The posterior part of the calcarine sulcus is an axial sulcus and the anterior part is a complete sulcus.

Therefore, among the options provided, the collateral sulcus is the best answer. 

Related Pearl: Classification of sulci of brain

Types of sulci:

On the basis of function, they're divided as:

  • Limiting sulcus - A sulcus that separates areas differing in structure and function at its floor. E.g. Central sulcus - separates motor and sensory area.
  • Axial sulcus - Sulcus that develops along the axis of a rapidly growing/ developing area. E.g. Posterior part of calcarine sulcus - primary visual area grows along this sulcus.
  • Operculated sulcus - A sulcus that separates two areas by its lip and contains a third area in its walls. E.g. Lunate sulcus - separates striate and peristriate areas.

On the basis of depth, they're divided as:

  • Complete sulcus - Deep enough to indent the wall of the lateral ventricle. E.g Anterior part of calcarine sulcus -  forms calcar avis at the lateral ventricle, Collateral sulcus -  forms collateral eminence at the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle
  • Incomplete sulcus - Superficially situated and does not indent the lateral ventricle. E.g. paracentral sulcus

questions.text: Anterior part of the calcarine sulcus is a _______.
questions.solution:
The anterior part of the calcarine sulcus is considered a complete sulcus because its depth creates an elevation in the medial wall of the occipital horn of the lateral ventricle. This is called the calcar avis.

However, the posterior part of the calcarine sulcus is considered an axial sulcus as its axis is along the visual cortex.

Heschl's gyrus is located in the primary auditory cortex (area 41, 42).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Area marked A is Broca's area (44, 45) and is present in the inferior frontal gyrus
Area marked B is the visual association Area (17, 18) and is present around the calcarine sulcus
Area marked C is the motor association area (5, 6) and is found in the superior parietal lobule
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is found in the middle frontal gyrus

questions.solution:
Area marked D is the frontal eye field (8) and is located in the posterior part of the middle frontal gyrus. It controls the conjugate movements of the eyes. It is connected to the visual part of the occipital cortex. 

Lesions here cause loss of horizontal conjugate movements.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Broca's aphasia in which the Broca's area will be affected.

In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia / Non-fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebral cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal or written words. The comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency.

Patients in whom the area is severely affected may have very few words to express all of their emotions.

questions.text: In individuals with a history of substance abuse and addiction, the marked structure is believed to trigger cravings on exposure to environmental cues. Which of the following is not true about the structure?

choices.text: It forms the base of the sylvian cistern
It lies between the frontal and temporal lobe
It receives somatosensory inputs from the entire body

questions.solution:
The structure marked by the arrow is the insular lobe. The insular cortex is not entirely agranular. The posterior part of the insular cortex is granular and the anterior part is agranular.

The insula forms the base of the Sylvian cistern and lies between the frontal and temporal lobes. It receives somatosensory, viscerosensory, homeostatic, and nociceptive information from the entire body. It receives inputs from the thalamus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a speech abnormality following a hemorrhagic stroke. He does not understand any written words or conversation. His speech is fluent but is incomprehensible. Repetition is also impaired.  Where is the lesion located?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, comprehension and repetition are impaired while the fluency is intact. This points to Wernicke’s aphasia. The area affected is Wernicke's area located in the superior temporal gyrus (marked 4). 

Broca’s motor speech area (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
